questions.question: We have a real-time application that sends messages at a very high frequency where we can tolerate up to 2% loss. Which transport layer protocol (layer 4) should be used for this application?

options.text: UDP
TCP
IP
ARP

questions.question: If a message is rejected by a router because it does not have enough capacity, how does IP handle this loss?

options.text: IP retransmet le message
IP will not even be aware of this loss, it is not part of its functionality
It asks the physical layer to retransmit
IP informs the destination to retransmit

questions.question: How does a machine get the MAC address of another machine on the same network?

options.text: By sending an ARP request in broadcast
MAC addresses are published on a server that the machine will request
The MAC address of the machines on the same network are given in the configuration
By sending an ARP request in unicast to the target machine

questions.question: How does a router know if a packet has been sent to it to be routed or if it is a packet that has been sent to it as an end destination (for it and not to be routed)?

options.text: A router never receives packets for itself, it receives always packets to route
By checking the source IP address to see if it is the same network
By checking the destination IP address
By checking the destination MAC address

questions.question: A message received by a switch is processed and then sent to the correct destination based on the destination MAC address. Which statement is correct?

options.text: A switch links the MAC addresses of the network machines to their IP addresses in a table
If the switch does not know the destination MAC address, it will reject the message

When the switch receives a message from a sender it does not know, it will link the sender's MAC address to the port number (port where the cable is connected on which it receives the message) in its switching table
When the switch receives a message from a sender it does not know, it will broadcast the message to the entire network

questions.question: Which field in the IP header is used to determine whether the packet encapsulates TCP or UDP?

options.text: Protocol
Port
Destination IP address
Version

questions.question: Which condition is necessary for proper addressing?

options.text: Two machines on two different networks must have the same value of the machine part of their IP addresses
Two machines on the same network must have the same value for the network portion of their IP addresses
Two machines on the same network must have the same value for the machine part of their IP addresses
Two machines on two different networks must have the same value of the network portion of their IP addresses

questions.question: Which statement is correct?

options.text: TCP identifies the different connections through MAC addresses
TCP allows to manage the loss of messages thanks to an acknowledgment technique
UDP manages connections using datagram sequence numbers
UDP allows a router to know which route to take

questions.question: Which layer is responsible for determining the next router when sending a message?

options.text: Layer 3
Layer 7
Layer 1
Layer 4

questions.question: We have a network that we want to divide into 2 subnetworks. We use the address 10.0.0.0/10 as a starting address. Which of the following addresses could be given to one of the two networks?
How does a machine check if it has the MAC address of the machine to contact ?

options.text: By looking in its ARP table
By looking at its interface configuration
By looking in its routing table
By asking the UDP protocol

questions.question: A machine wants to send a packet to a remote machine (in another network) but it does not have its IP address. Which of the following statements is correct.

options.text: It sends in broadcast and the machine in question accepts the packet
It will be able to convert its MAC address into an IP address
It sends using the address of the router
It will not be able to send the IP packet

questions.question: What does a machine do when it receives an ARP request containing its IP address?

options.text: it retransmits the ARP request to a server that manages the IP-MAC addresses correspondence
it sends an ARP response to the machine that sent the request
it sends an ARP response in broadcast on the network
it sends an IP packet , in response to the ARP request, to the machine that sent the request

questions.question: Given the following configuration, which route is correct on machine A to reach machine B?

options.text: Destination: 10.2.1.0/16, next router: 10.2.1.3
Destination: 10.2.0.0/16, next router: 10.1.1.3
Destination: 10.2.1.0/16, next router: 10.1.1.3
Destination: 10.2.0.0/16, next router: 10.2.1.3

questions.question: A machine A sends a message to a machine B in the same network, the two machines are connected via a switch. In which case a collision can take place ?

options.text: When the two messages cross on the cable connecting the switch to machine B
When the two messages cross on one of the two machines
When the two messages cross on the switch

questions.question: What happens if a machine with the address 192.168.1.1/24 sends a message to an IP address 192.168.1.4/24 that is not assigned to any machine in its network?

options.text: The message will be sent and no machine will receive it
By applying the mask, the sending machine will know that the destination IP address does not correspond to any machine in the network and reject the message
The sending machine will not be able to obtain the MAC address of the destination machine and will never send the message

questions.question: When an application message is sent, the transmitting machine encapsulates it in a layer 4 message, which is then encapsulated in turn in a layer 3 packet. Which proposition is correct?

options.text: In this encapsulation process, each layer (3 and 4) adds addresses of different types
In this encapsulation process, each layer (3 and 4) adds information necessary for the sending of the data to the destination application
In this encapsulation process, layer 3 checks the message given by layer 4 before encapsulating it
In this encapsulation process, layer 4 adds information that is used by the routers routing the data to the destination

questions.question: Which information is used to determine the next machine to contact to route the data to the destination?

options.text: a sequence number
the window size
the destination MAC address
a port number

questions.question: Two machines A and B are on two different networks interconnected by routers on the Internet. To allow communication between A and B, which proposition is correct?

options.text: A and B must use the same type of physical medium
A and B and all routers must use the same Layer 3 protocol
A and B can use different Layer 4 protocols
A and B must use the same protocols on all layers

questions.question: A machine A wants to send a message to a machine B in another network than A. Which destination IP address will A put in the IP packet?

options.text: IP adresse of the router connected to the network of A
IP adresse of the router connected to the network of B
IP adresse of B

questions.question: When does machine A use an ARP request?

options.text: When machine A does not have the MAC address of the destination host
To get a MAC address from a port number
To get an IP address from a MAC address
When the interface of machine A does not have an assigned MAC address

questions.question: Which of the following properties characterizes a router?

options.text: It divides the network into multiple broadcast domains
It retransmits data in case of loss
It gives sequence numbers to the messages it transfers
It directs the flow to a particular application

questions.question: Which of the following is not relevant to the TCP protocol?

options.text: Manage the splitting of the application flow into several messages
Manage the addresses given to the two extremities machines
Manage data multiplexing with port numbers
Manage the flow with the reception windows

questions.question: Let a message be sent from an application AP1 on a machine A to an AP2 application on a machine B. Which layer allows the machines to know that the transmission is going from AP1 et AP2 and not other applications?

options.text: Layer 4
Layer 1
Layer 7
Layer 3
Layer 2

questions.question: A router connecting two networks receives a message from network 1. How does it know if it is an IP packet to route or a packet of another protocol?

options.text: A router only receives IP packets, so this is always the case
Looking at the size of the message
It looks at the value of the "length/type" field of the layer 2 Ethernet header
By looking if the MAC address matches

questions.question: Why does a machine need both IP address and a MAC address to send a message to another machine?

options.text: Because an IP address is not stable
Because a message can pass through several machines to reach the destination
To guarantee uniqueness of the destination and to be sure that it is the right destination
To allow the receiving machine to check that the message is sent to it

questions.question: A machine A sends a message to a machine B directly connected to it. Which proposition is correct ?

options.text: If a collision occurs, machine A will, in all cases, be aware of the collision
If a collision occurs machine A might not be aware of the collision, other layers will detect the loss and ensure retransmission
If a collision occurs, it is the physical layer that will manage the detection and retransmission of the message
If machine A detects the collision, it will ask layer 3 to retransmit

questions.question: During the process of receiving a message, what is the first information used by the receiving machine to accept or reject a received message?

options.text: The destination IP address
The preamble of the Ethernet frame
The error check sequence
The destination MAC address

questions.question: A machine A and a machine B are directly connected by a cable. To ensure communication between A and B. Which proposition is correct?

options.text: A and B can use different Layer 2 protocols
A and B can use different Layer 3 protocols
All protocols of the different layers must be the same on both machines
A and B may use different methods of accessing the medium

questions.question: Which statement is correct regarding the IP protocol ?

options.text: It avoids overloading the network by limiting the flow
It retransmits the message in case of collision
It allows machines to perform the necessary actions that allow messages to reach a remote destination
It puts back in order the messages at the reception

questions.question: We have two machines A and B connected by a switch. Which statement is correct?

options.text: To avoid a collision, machine A avoids sending, when a signal leaves the switch to go to machine A
To avoid a collision, machine A avoids sending when a signal is going from B to the switch
To avoid a collision, machine A avoids sending when the switch is processing data

questions.question: In a network 172.16.0.0/16, which of the following addresses can we give to a machine?
A router connects two local networks, network R1 and network R2. What type of coding is possible on the two networks so that they are compatible.

options.text: Manchester on R1 - NRZ on R2
Manchester on R1 - Amplitude Modulation on R2
Amplitude Modulation on R1 - Amplitude Modulation on R2

questions.question: On a machine A, what are the MAC addresses kept in the ARP table?

options.text: The MAC addresses of the machines that A has contacted and that are in a different network than A
The MAC addresses of the machines that A has contacted and that are in the same network as A
MAC addresses of all machines in the same network as A
The MAC addresses of the machines that the router of A's network has contacted

questions.question: A router receives a packet with a destination IP address that matches its address and a MAC address that is different from its address. What does it do with the packet?

options.text: It routes it to the machine that has the destination MAC address
It considers that the packet was intended for it
It rejects the packet at layer 2
It discards the packet at layer 3

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: A message sent from a machine A to a machine B in another network is encapsulated in a level 2 ethernet frame to avoid collisions
A message sent from a machine A to a machine B in another network is encapsulated in a level 2 ethernet frame to detect if a transmission error has occurred
A message sent from machine A to machine B in another network is encapsulated in a Layer 2 ethernet frame in order to be routed to the destination
A message sent from a machine A to a machine B in another network is encapsulated in a Layer 2 ethernet frame to ensure compatibility between A and B

questions.question: An IP address given to a machine is composed of what parts?

options.text: Machine-ID and application-ID
Network-ID, Machine-ID and constructor-ID
Network-ID and Machine-ID
Network-ID, Machine-ID and Broadcast-ID

questions.question: How does a machine know if another machine is in the same network as it or in a different network?

options.text: by applying the mask to the destination IP address
by checking its routing table
by testing with a broadcast message
by comparing its MAC address to that of the destination machine

questions.question: Why do we need a Layer 3 protocol if Layer 2 protocols can identify machines with a MAC address?

options.text: To manage the flow of data
To interconnect machines belonging to different networks
To carry data to the application
To provide a security layer
